On 9/1/09, vairam99

Hi Ravi,

You are clearly getting confused with this topic.
Let me start of with the basics,

Karthigesu Sivathambi in his work"literary history of Tamil Literature"
details the two modes of history through Literature.

Literary History and History of Literature.

Literary History:
To study the literature to understand the people who have written the
literature , their social status, their economic status, their pass times
etc. Tamils 1800 years ago,Study in Tamil by Raghava Iyengar.
All of Sangam Tamilians history is Literary History.

Say lets take eg. lets take the Movie Subramaniya Puram. Suppose after some
500 years they see this movie.
They would make observations like in 1980s they used to was pant and shirt ,
women used to were Sari. Around Madurai region there was lot of violence.
Heaving beard was a style.Rajnikanth was a very popular actor.

History of Literature:
To study the history of the literature itself rather than the content of it.
Books like Tamil Literature by Venugopala Pillai, History of Tamil
Literature by Kamil Zvelebil,History of Tamil Literature by Jesudasan.

This approach is like when people watch Subramaniyapuram 500 years later,
they would observe(if they didnt know when the movie released)
The movie must not have been taken in 1980s since
The photography standards have improved
It has heavy influence of Spanish cinema which is very late development
The actor Sasi Kumar can also be found nearly in the same get up in film
Nadodigal which is closely dates around 2010.
The same can be said of other cast because all of them seem to be of the
period around 2010.
This film should have been released before the movie Pasanga,Mothi
Vilayadu,Saroja because all these movie have mentioned Suramaniyapuram.
SO Lower limit of the films age is around 2009 .
The movie also seems to have been a realistic movie.This wave was supposedly
started by a movie Kadhal. So the upper limit can be kept as 2005.
So the movie should have been released in some where between 2007-2008.

----
These are the available methods of study for Reader of History in
literature. So it is not important for the history scholar to analyse the
filming technique ( though he would touch on it to say - as an evidence) or
production values or acting skills of the film.
Reader of History can only do this much.

If you want whole analysis of the film,then only a film critic can do it ,
or if you want to know the religious aspects of the film only religious
expert can do it.

History expert when taking a subject can write based only upon proven
evidences or related to History in the above mentioned approaches.

---
If your reader of literature or a Linguist you can give critical analysison
a subject. This is different from commentary.A critical analysis of
Thirumanthiram would have what diseases are being discussed - comparison of
the remedy with the present day remedies- all these.
---

Dr.Zvelebil's Tamil Literature- the one under discussion for the Alwar
content is work of History on Tamil Literature.

Smile of Murugan is work of linguist in trying to popularize a language
called Tamil to the world.

His Murugan works:
Tamil Traditions of Subrahmanya Murga -
Chronicles all the legends and myths in first part and gives critical
analysis on the sources.
Thiru Murugan -
Is set of 5 essays - it doesn't belong to any particular genre
Because some essays are critical analysis,some are papers on Philosophy.
Tamil Kandha Puranam - Short summary (in english) and critical Analysis.

---

Now regarding Alwar- dating, his work is as a Historian. (Please see the
Subramaniyapuram example of History of Literature). This work of his is
unparallel and still today considered the reference for nearly all papers
written on Tamil.

So as a historian person would only look for history.As a Linguist and
reader of literature would only look in finer aspects of the language.

So to read Zvelebil and expect the philosophical depth or any thing other
than History or as a reader of Literature would end up in a bad way. This
failure is not contributed by the Author.

Regards,
Vairam

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Hello Vairam

Enna sir periya varthai, hijack, ellam solaringa... :-) I have posed the
gap questions on the previous email (Refer Sooran - Mahendra puram etc).

Alwars are real, but what they sung were a myth..(??).
If one alwar used another one's theory as a base line, it makes sense on
the base line start concept, which again comes back to me that Dr.Zvelebil
may have had a western base line.

If Murugan is a myth, then why are there so much different historical
references ? Poratha kulapathukku, pal veru Murugan vere, version control
problem irukke?

Ancient Dravidian Murugan or Ceyyon, was still a myth to start with...
according to Dr.Zvelebil and other western scholars??. In this
case,history has no standing without the strong myth background.

Myth-History may not always,coexist, especially where history has many
patches where as myth does not, it is, but natural, that history MUST be
proper in its explanations.And historians must have a convincing record to
prove when researching myth or our foundational thoughts.If our current
human mind cannot comprehend, we cannot conclude that this is a bard's
tale and cannot be real.

Without Murugan the myth, what would have been a start for this research
anyway.

Itheppadi irukkuna, there is a story about a mid sea accident with no
survivors, what an oxymoron! If there are no survivors, how does the story
come by?

I am a believer, but I do have a rational thought. I do not question all
the contemporary historical thoughts, Simply those that do not make sense.

As much as yourself or Dr.Zvelebil(rest his soul), I am in search of
Murugan, just that I expect him in reality.If history can show me where he
is or what he is, it would make my life more easy and possibly a short cut
:-).

Heinrich Schliemann found Troy, exactly where Iliad stated Troy was, now
that is myth becoming history. Troy is not without Achilles or Hector, but
then was Achillies the son of Thetis - a sea nymph.
Troy is real - history it became one from the myth, but just because
Achilles's birth data is not documented or found, we cannot, until then
say Thetis was not a sea nymph, how ever hard it would be for our
scientific mind to accept.

-R

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

Hi Ravi ,

you seemed to have hijacked the topic.
My question was very specific regarding the pages in discussion. You
said you have feeling that there is gaps in his dating of alwars.
It would be better if you can explain it.

Murugan its always argumentative in this forum whether its myth or
history.

But Alwars are for sure history and not Myth - and I would like to know
what gaps you have found in that.

I guess you are still in Hangover over the Murugan History debate we had
year ago!

I surely do not wish to start the Murugan debate again. You are a
believer and I am in search of History. No use we two arguing.
Writer of History can base his arguments and on what is found and what
can be proved or at least tentatively proved/accepted.
Myth and history can never co exist. Your argument can also be held
against various Indian Scholars then - Romila Thapar, Jesudasan and
other major Tamil Scholars. It has no western mind applied to it. If
finding evidence to validate a claim is western mind - then I am here to
welcome it. Archeology,numismatic are product of western mind.

Lets put this talk very specific to Alwars else we are entering the
labyrinth again.

Regards,
Vairam

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Dear Vairam

Dr.Zvelebil was an undisputed scholar who came in from the west and
studied Dravidian history more than any of us can even imagine. I have
never disputed that, will never do that too, in that count.

However, please understand that there MUST be a base line for
anything, no one can start any such colossal work without having a
base line, a starting point. For many of us it was PS or SS or
something similar. For Dr.Zvelebil, who or what was it?

I believe it could have been from Odysseus the Greek hero of Trojan
War (he mentions about this fav char in his article Hippalos).
Dr.Zvelebil, was very much knowledgeable and interested in the Greek
myth apart from various languages. He even made a comparative study of
Muruga with Dionysus. Again, nothing wrong!

He was more interested in the History of Tamil Literature than the
literature itself.

For me, there in is one of the issues. I believe the literature and
history of literature are very closely intertwined, my mythological
foundation makes it believe so, a hard line western or dk thought may
not be so.

Dr.Zvelebil wrote history, not the biography of Murugan. He is
entitled to the crown on his historical findings, though a study on
Muruga is never complete 'even' with a total analysis of Guru
Arunagiri's works.

As said by the Guru: "Ariya ariya ariyaatha, adigal ariya,
adiyeenum,arivul ariyum arivura, arulvaaye"

I have read his translation on Anubuthi, one of Guru's works. I
noticed that he was emphasizing on the literal value of the poem,
while Guru Arunagiri (even according to Dr.Zvelebil) who was not just
a simple poet.

Ex: Verse 51, Guru Arunagiri uses the term `Guhane', which by itself
makes a mile of difference – the usage of that term, on how a person
approaches a specific concept, there is the difference between
literacy and historical interpretation of literacy. I think I had
written about this earlier too.

I am not convinced on his theory on Cur becoming Curan etc, so the
location of Mahendrapuram is dismissed as myth and obviously many such
thoughts on the subject. While it is difficult to excavate a city from
a spot such as where Mahendrapuram would have existed to prove it was
there, it is also difficult to prove …it was not there.
Tarakasuran is termed as a Northern demon, later linked with Suran as
a brother etc. To some degree, there seems to be a named similarity,
with a demon that was possessing similar qualities somewhere in the
southern vindya ranges. Thiruthani is said to be a resting place for
the Lord post Tarakasuran destruction, again history has no clue for
it. I believe Thiruthani existance is way before pallava time, i had
this question posed before too.

I do not see the difference between Bogar's palani and Thiru
avinankudi analysis as much as I would like to see. Bogar's age – his
time line of alchemy practice vs. construction of palani idol, why
there and not at Avinan kudi?

When 1800 year old pallava construction (and sangam works below it)
was only found in 2008/9 even so it was near to the great pagodas, the
odds of real history of Murugan not being clearly found is quite
possible.

Ultimately, does he conclude the existence of Murugan after all this
research?

Dr.Zvelebil does have excellent work accomplished, I am humble enough
to accept that I neither posses the qualification nor the experience
to question his findings. However, just like him, I am entitled to my
opinion.

Nearly 40 years of Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we
are.

Tamilian, is a feeling that does not tie an age factor or research to
it, Dr.Zvelebil was a tamil by heart, agreed – purely due tohis
dedication on research of these ancient works, which not many dare to
tread.

However, to generalize the words `than we are' may not be very
relevant in all comparisons.

Today, there are many excellent tamil scholars who can read these
literature – just as literature and not as an embodied sweatof bhakti
cult or belief/faith in the Ultimate. That takes the soul out of these
writings, though it makes them a good read some times even with awe.

However, I would price these lower than any contemporary classic, even
say they be Sanskrit adopted like tamilian kanda puranam.
These poets are tamil too, and nothing wrong with their opinions,
though many do not agree.

PS: That I read thiru murugatru padai, I may possess some
argumentative qualities of Nakkirar 
- R
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

Hi Ravi,
Dr.Zvelebil most of the time, acts just as accumulator of data in
his book Tamil literature. He consolidates all the dating given by
various scholar till his time and gives his explanation for his
dating. He leaves to the reader to accumulate the data and make up
their minds.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and
research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I sure by making this comment you have read the page 152 to 161 of
his great work Tamil Literature. As usual he has given dating of all
Indian scholars and his dating. So it would be really helpful to all
members of the group if you can let us know the important gaps he
has left in these pages.

I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and cultural
onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a base
line that starts with a western ideology.
Unlike George L Hart or A K Ramanujan - his works have never been
controversial. He was more interested in the History of Tamil
Literature than the literature itself. Only other western scholar to
my knowledge who has done research on Tamil history is JR Marr (his
great work - The Eight Anthologies).
He was one of the western scholars to have put weight behind the
claim for Tamil as a classical Language(argued literary in every
book of his , how ancient the language was - in a time where Tamil
was belived to an off spring of Sanskrit by scholars like KAN
Tamil. Nearly 40 years of Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than
we are(N.Ganesan sir pointed out he calls his daughter Kanamma). I
request you to read his short biography by Dr.Elangovan in his blog
http://muelangovan.blogspot.com/2008/11/17-11-1927.html

So put such charge on him would require some valid reasons from you
, which I am sure you would have it. I wouldbe interested to hear
your views on Dr.Zvelebil's works.

Regards,
Vairam
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

History does not account for various stories and tales of the
bard, which seems to be having many lines of history before being
sung.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and
research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and cultural
onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a base
line that starts with a western ideology.

Nothing wrong, but then there are gaps that can derail a train.

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

of various scholars. Usually after 1975 all works quote this
book for dating of various literature.

*From:* vj kumar *To:* ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com

*Subject:* Re: [ponniyinselvan] Re: Kannappar

good questions venkat

Karaikkal ammai and kannapar are the most early.

Below, clarifications from Sri Subramaniam ( his site
http://www.geocities.com/nayanmars/) - great teacher - most
of my posts on
periapurnam panels of darasuram are with his blessings and
guidance ( must
thank Dhivakar sir once again for introducing him to me)

Kannappar is mentioned by manikkavasagar in tiruvasagam,
while the
language used by ammai dates her between 2 - 5th C and not
later than that
for sure.

Ammai:

http://www.thevaara m.org/thirumurai _1/nayanmar_ view.php?

On Mon, Aug 31, 2009 at 2:26 AM, TM Sunder com wrote:

It is difficult to determine decisively who is ancient
among the
nayanmars, nor the Thiruthondar Puranam that lists
hagiography of 63 saints
and 9 Thogai adiyargal is conclusively exhaustive. For
example, Auvayar is
not in the list. There are countless devotees over the ages
have
dedicated themselves to the pathway to realization of God
through bhakti.

Maani-k-ka vasagar is perhaps oldest in the list of 63.

#31
dmaloo
Offline
Joined: 08/14/2009
Kannappar

Sampath, history can become myth and myth can become history over time, both are true, not necessarily one or the other. Ravana was a king of lanka ishistory (maybe), ravana had ten heads is myth (most probably). Mary was the mother of Jesus is history but Mary was a virgin mother is myth. Unfortunately people have lost the ability to distinguish what is what. Just

Another example - Draupadi married to five men is actually metaphysically the soul wedded to its five senses. If you dive deep into metaphysical meaningso f the MAhabharat is a fascinating, rich and unbelivable metaphor for spiritual challenges. Instead of learning from that people waste time debating on how one woman wedded to five men is a 'karpukkarasi', Draupadi was attracted to KArna and even Sri Krishna, on and on the ridiculous arguments continue. That is the sad plight of mistaking myth to be history and fact.

Malathi
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ssampath108"

I fully agree with you, Ravi.

My English Professor, defined king as a small emperor and emperor as a
big king.

History, when proved, is a small or a portion myth; and, when validated
history is proved false, it again becomes a myth. Myth is also history
in a sense, because we have several versions of myths, as we have
several versions of history (jinnah, freedom movement, partition, role
of Gandhi etc.)

It is preferable not to get swayed or bulldozed by the 'scientific' tag
attached to extrapolated and biased versions of 'history'.

Sampath
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Hello Vairam

Enna sir periya varthai, hijack, ellam solaringa... :-) I have posed
the gap questions on the previous email (Refer Sooran - Mahendra puram
etc).

Alwars are real, but what they sung were a myth..(??).
If one alwar used another one's theory as a base line, it makes sense
on the base line start concept, which again comes back to me that
Dr.Zvelebil may have had a western base line.

If Murugan is a myth, then why are there so much different historical
references ? Poratha kulapathukku, pal veru Murugan vere, version
control problem irukke?

Ancient Dravidian Murugan or Ceyyon, was still a myth to start with...
according to Dr.Zvelebil and other western scholars??. In this
case,history has no standing without the strong myth background.

Myth-History may not always,coexist, especially where history has many
patches where as myth does not, it is, but natural, that history MUST be
proper in its explanations.And historians must have a convincing record
to prove when researching myth or our foundational thoughts.If our
current human mind cannot comprehend, we cannot conclude that this is a
bard's tale and cannot be real.

Without Murugan the myth, what would have been a start for this
research anyway.

Itheppadi irukkuna, there is a story about a mid sea accident with no
survivors, what an oxymoron! If there are no survivors, how does the
story come by?

I am a believer, but I do have a rational thought. I do not question
all the contemporary historical thoughts, Simply those that do not make
sense.

As much as yourself or Dr.Zvelebil(rest his soul), I am in search of
Murugan, just that I expect him in reality.If history can show me where
he is or what he is, it would make my life more easy and possibly a
short cut :-).

Heinrich Schliemann found Troy, exactly where Iliad stated Troy was,
now that is myth becoming history. Troy is not without Achilles or
Hector, but then was Achillies the son of Thetis - a sea nymph.
Troy is real - history it became one from the myth, but just because
Achilles's birth data is not documented or found, we cannot, until then
say Thetis was not a sea nymph, how ever hard it would be for our
scientific mind to accept.

-R

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99" vairam@ wrote:

you seemed to have hijacked the topic.

It would be better if you can explain it.

Murugan its always argumentative in this forum whether its myth or
history.

But Alwars are for sure history and not Myth - and I would like to
know what gaps you have found in that.

I guess you are still in Hangover over the Murugan History debate we
had year ago!

I surely do not wish to start the Murugan debate again. You are a
believer and I am in search of History. No use we two arguing.
Writer of History can base his arguments and on what is found and
what can be proved or at least tentatively proved/accepted.
Myth and history can never co exist. Your argument can also be held
against various Indian Scholars then - Romila Thapar, Jesudasan and
other major Tamil Scholars. It has no western mind applied to it. If
finding evidence to validate a claim is western mind - then I am here to
welcome it. Archeology,numismatic are product of western mind.

Lets put this talk very specific to Alwars else we are entering the
labyrinth again.

Regards,
Vairam

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Dear Vairam

Dr.Zvelebil was an undisputed scholar who came in from the west
and studied Dravidian history more than any of us can even imagine. I
have never disputed that, will never do that too, in that count.

However, please understand that there MUST be a base line for
anything, no one can start any such colossal work without having a base
line, a starting point. For many of us it was PS or SS or something
similar. For Dr.Zvelebil, who or what was it?

I believe it could have been from Odysseus the Greek hero of
Trojan War (he mentions about this fav char in his article Hippalos).
Dr.Zvelebil, was very much knowledgeable and interested in the
Greek myth apart from various languages. He even made a comparative
study of Muruga with Dionysus. Again, nothing wrong!

He was more interested in the History of Tamil Literature than
the literature itself.

For me, there in is one of the issues. I believe the literature
and history of literature are very closely intertwined, my mythological
foundation makes it believe so, a hard line western or dk thought may
not be so.

Dr.Zvelebil wrote history, not the biography of Murugan. He is
entitled to the crown on his historical findings, though a study on
Muruga is never complete 'even' with a total analysis of Guru
Arunagiri's works.

As said by the Guru: "Ariya ariya ariyaatha, adigal ariya,
adiyeenum,arivul ariyum arivura, arulvaaye"

I have read his translation on Anubuthi, one of Guru's works. I
noticed that he was emphasizing on the literal value of the poem, while
Guru Arunagiri (even according to Dr.Zvelebil) who was not just a simple
poet.

Ex: Verse 51, Guru Arunagiri uses the term `Guhane', which by
itself makes a mile of difference ? the usage of that term, on how a
person approaches a specific concept, there is the difference between
literacy and historical interpretation of literacy. I think I had
written about this earlier too.

I am not convinced on his theory on Cur becoming Curan etc, so the
location of Mahendrapuram is dismissed as myth and obviously many such
thoughts on the subject. While it is difficult to excavate a city from a
spot such as where Mahendrapuram would have existed to prove it was
there, it is also difficult to prove ?it was not there.
Tarakasuran is termed as a Northern demon, later linked with Suran
as a brother etc. To some degree, there seems to be a named similarity,
with a demon that was possessing similar qualities somewhere in the
southern vindya ranges. Thiruthani is said to be a resting place for the
Lord post Tarakasuran destruction, again history has no clue for it. I
believe Thiruthani existance is way before pallava time, i had this
question posed before too.

I do not see the difference between Bogar's palani and Thiru
avinankudi analysis as much as I would like to see. Bogar's age ?
his time line of alchemy practice vs. construction of palani idol, why
there and not at Avinan kudi?

When 1800 year old pallava construction (and sangam works below
it) was only found in 2008/9 even so it was near to the great pagodas,
the odds of real history of Murugan not being clearly found is quite
possible.

Ultimately, does he conclude the existence of Murugan after all
this research?

Dr.Zvelebil does have excellent work accomplished, I am humble
enough to accept that I neither posses the qualification nor the
experience to question his findings. However, just like him, I am
entitled to my opinion.

Nearly 40 years of Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we
are.

Tamilian, is a feeling that does not tie an age factor or research
to it, Dr.Zvelebil was a tamil by heart, agreed ? purely due to his
dedication on research of these ancient works, which not many dare to
tread.

However, to generalize the words `than we are' may not be very
relevant in all comparisons.

Today, there are many excellent tamil scholars who can read these
literature ? just as literature and not as an embodied sweat of
bhakti cult or belief/faith in the Ultimate. That takes the soul out of
these writings, though it makes them a good read some times even with
awe.

However, I would price these lower than any contemporary classic,
even say they be Sanskrit adopted like tamilian kanda puranam.
These poets are tamil too, and nothing wrong with their opinions,
though many do not agree.

PS: That I read thiru murugatru padai, I may possess some
argumentative qualities of Nakkirar 
- R
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

Hi Ravi,
Dr.Zvelebil most of the time, acts just as accumulator of data
in his book Tamil literature. He consolidates all the dating given by
various scholar till his time and gives his explanation for his dating.
He leaves to the reader to accumulate the data and make up their minds.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and
research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I sure by making this comment you have read the page 152 to 161
of his great work Tamil Literature. As usual he has given dating of all
Indian scholars and his dating. So it would be really helpful to all
members of the group if you can let us know the important gaps he has
left in these pages.

I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and
cultural onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a
base line that starts with a western ideology.
Unlike George L Hart or A K Ramanujan - his works have never
been controversial. He was more interested in the History of Tamil
Literature than the literature itself. Only other western scholar to my
knowledge who has done research on Tamil history is JR Marr (his great
work - The Eight Anthologies).
He was one of the western scholars to have put weight behind the
claim for Tamil as a classical Language(argued literary in every book of
his , how ancient the language was - in a time where Tamil was belived
nearly 1990 he has done field research in Tamil. Nearly 40 years of
Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we are(N.Ganesan sir pointed
out he calls his daughter Kanamma). I request you to read his short
biography by Dr.Elangovan in his blog
http://muelangovan.blogspot.com/2008/11/17-11-1927.html

So put such charge on him would require some valid reasons from
you , which I am sure you would have it. I wouldbe interested to hear
your views on Dr.Zvelebil's works.

Regards,
Vairam
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds" wrote:

History does not account for various stories and tales of the
bard, which seems to be having many lines of history before being sung.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and
research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and
cultural onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a
base line that starts with a western ideology.

Nothing wrong, but then there are gaps that can derail a
train.

rgds
vj

http://www.poetryinstone.in
Here the language of stone surpasses the language of man

2009/8/31 TM Sunder

Brilliant, VJ. Thanks for providing link to Sri.
Subramniams' website.

*From:* vj kumar *To:* ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com
*Sent:* Sunday, August 30, 2009 10:35:57 PM
*Subject:* Re: [ponniyinselvan] Re: Kannappar

good questions venkat

Karaikkal ammai and kannapar are the most early.

Below, clarifications from Sri Subramaniam ( his site
http://www.geocities.com/nayanmars/) - great teacher -
most of my posts on
periapurnam panels of darasuram are with his blessings
and guidance ( must
thank Dhivakar sir once again for introducing him to me)

Kannappar is mentioned by manikkavasagar in tiruvasagam,
while the
language used by ammai dates her between 2 - 5th C and
not later than that
for sure.

Ammai:

http://www.thevaara m.org/thirumurai _1/nayanmar_
view.php? nayan_idField=

16 =16

இவரது யாப்பமைதி
சொற்பொருள் அமைதி
முதலியவற்றைக்
கொண்டு ஆராயுங்கால்
இவரது
காலம் இருண்ட
காலப்பகுதி
எனப்படும். கி.பி.
நான்கு அல்லது
ஐந்தாம்
நூற்றாண்டாகக்
கொள்ளலாம் என்பதும்
ஆய்வாளர்களின்
கருத்தாகும்.

Mention of kannappar in Tiruvasagam by manikkavasa gar
http://www.tamilnat ion.org/sathyam/ east/thiruvasaga
m/tvasagam10.
htm

*திருக்கோத்தும்பி -
சிவனோடு ஐக்கியம்*
(தில்லையில்
அருளியது-நாலடித்
தரவு கொச்சகக்
கலிப்பா)

பூவேறு கோனும்
புரந்தரனும்
பொற்பமைந்த
நாவேறு
செல்வியும் நாரணணும்
நான் மறையும்
மாவேறு சோதியும்
வானவருந் தாமறியாச்
சேவேறு
சேவடிக்கே
சென்றுதாய்
கோத்தும்பீ. 215

நானார் என்
உள்ளமார் ஞானங்க
ளார் என்னை யாரறிவார்
வானோர்
பிரானென்னை
ஆண்டிலனேல் மதிமயங்கி
ஊனா ருடைதலையில்
உண்பலிதேர் அம்பலவன்
தேனார் கமலமே
சென்றூதாய்
கோத்தும்பீ. 216

தினைத்தனை
உள்ளதோர் பூவினில்
தேன்உண்ணாதே
நினைத்தொறும்
காண்தொறும்
பேசுந்தொறும்
எப்போதும்
அனைத்தெலும்
புள்நெக ஆனந்தத்
தேன் சொரியும்

குனிப்புடையானுக்கே
சென்றூதாய்
கோத்தும்பீ. 217

*கண்ணப்பன்**
??'ப்பதோர் அன்பின்மை
கண்டபின் *
என்னப்பன்
என்னொப்பில்
என்னையும்
ஆட்கொண்டருளி
வண்ணப்
பணித்தென்னை வாவென்ற
வான் கருணைச்
கண்ணப்பென்
நீற்றற்கே
சென்றூதாய்
கோத்தும்பீ. 218

http://www.poetryinstone.in
Here the language of stone surpasses the language of man

On Mon, Aug 31, 2009 at 2:26 AM, TM Sunder

It is difficult to determine decisively who is ancient
among the
nayanmars, nor the Thiruthondar Puranam that lists
hagiography of 63 saints
and 9 Thogai adiyargal is conclusively exhaustive. For
example, Auvayar is
not in the list. There are countless devotees over the
ages have
dedicated themselves to the pathway to realization of
God through bhakti.

Maani-k-ka vasagar is perhaps oldest in the list of 63.

vairam99

Kannappar

Hi Ravi,

You are clearly getting confused with this topic.
Let me start of with the basics,

Karthigesu Sivathambi in his work"literary history of Tamil Literature" details the two modes of history through Literature.

Literary History and History of Literature.

Literary History:
To study the literature to understand the people who have written the literature , their social status, their economic status, their pass times etc. Tamils 1800 years ago,Study in Tamil by Raghava Iyengar.
All of Sangam Tamilians history is Literary History.

Say lets take eg. lets take the Movie Subramaniya Puram. Suppose after some500 years they see this movie.
They would make observations like in 1980s they used to was pant and shirt , women used to were Sari. Around Madurai region there was lot of violence.Heaving beard was a style.Rajnikanth was a very popular actor.

History of Literature:
To study the history of the literature itself rather than the content of it. Books like Tamil Literature by Venugopala Pillai, History of Tamil Literature by Kamil Zvelebil,History of Tamil Literature by Jesudasan.

This approach is like when people watch Subramaniyapuram 500 years later, they would observe(if they didnt know when the movie released)
The movie must not have been taken in 1980s since
The photography standards have improved
It has heavy influence of Spanish cinema which is very late development
The actor Sasi Kumar can also be found nearly in the same get up in film Nadodigal which is closely dates around 2010.
The same can be said of other cast because all of them seem to be of the period around 2010.
This film should have been released before the movie Pasanga,Mothi Vilayadu,Saroja because all these movie have mentioned Suramaniyapuram.
SO Lower limit of the films age is around 2009 .
The movie also seems to have been a realistic movie.This wave was supposedly started by a movie Kadhal. So the upper limit can be kept as 2005.
So the movie should have been released in some where between 2007-2008.

----
These are the available methods of study for Reader of History in literature. So it is not important for the history scholar to analyse the filming technique ( though he would touch on it to say - as an evidence) or production values or acting skills of the film.
Reader of History can only do this much.

If you want whole analysis of the film,then only a film critic can do it , or if you want to know the religious aspects of the film only religious expert can do it.

History expert when taking a subject can write based only upon proven evidences or related to History in the above mentioned approaches.

---
If your reader of literature or a Linguist you can give critical analysis on a subject. This is different from commentary.A critical analysis of Thirumanthiram would have what diseases are being discussed - comparison of the remedy with the present day remedies- all these.
---

Dr.Zvelebil's Tamil Literature- the one under discussion for the Alwar content is work of History on Tamil Literature.

Smile of Murugan is work of linguist in trying to popularize a language called Tamil to the world.

His Murugan works:
Tamil Traditions of Subrahmanya Murga -
Chronicles all the legends and myths in first part and gives critical analysis on the sources.
Thiru Murugan -
Is set of 5 essays - it doesn't belong to any particular genre
Because some essays are critical analysis,some are papers on Philosophy.
Tamil Kandha Puranam - Short summary (in english) and critical Analysis.

---

Now regarding Alwar- dating, his work is as a Historian. (Please see the Subramaniyapuram example of History of Literature). This work of his is unparallel and still today considered the reference for nearly all papers written on Tamil.

So as a historian person would only look for history.As a Linguist and reader of literature would only look in finer aspects of the language.

So to read Zvelebil and expect the philosophical depth or any thing other than History or as a reader of Literature would end up in a bad way. This failure is not contributed by the Author.

Regards,
Vairam

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Hello Vairam

Enna sir periya varthai, hijack, ellam solaringa... :-) I have posed the gap questions on the previous email (Refer Sooran - Mahendra puram etc).

Alwars are real, but what they sung were a myth..(??).
If one alwar used another one's theory as a base line, it makes sense on the base line start concept, which again comes back to me that Dr.Zvelebil may have had a western base line.

If Murugan is a myth, then why are there so much different historical references ? Poratha kulapathukku, pal veru Murugan vere, version control problem irukke?

Ancient Dravidian Murugan or Ceyyon, was still a myth to start with... according to Dr.Zvelebil and other western scholars??. In this case,history has no standing without the strong myth background.

Myth-History may not always,coexist, especially where history has many patches where as myth does not, it is, but natural, that history MUST be proper in its explanations.And historians must have a convincing record to prove when researching myth or our foundational thoughts.If our current human mind cannot comprehend, we cannot conclude that this is a bard's tale and cannot be real.

Without Murugan the myth, what would have been a start for this research anyway.

Itheppadi irukkuna, there is a story about a mid sea accident with no survivors, what an oxymoron! If there are no survivors, how does the story come by?

I am a believer, but I do have a rational thought. I do not question all the contemporary historical thoughts, Simply those that do not make sense.

As much as yourself or Dr.Zvelebil(rest his soul), I am in search of Murugan, just that I expect him in reality.If history can show me where he is or what he is, it would make my life more easy and possibly a short cut :-).

Heinrich Schliemann found Troy, exactly where Iliad stated Troy was, now that is myth becoming history. Troy is not without Achilles or Hector, but then was Achillies the son of Thetis - a sea nymph.
Troy is real - history it became one from the myth, but just because Achilles's birth data is not documented or found, we cannot, until then say Thetis was not a sea nymph, how ever hard it would be for our scientific mind to accept.

-R

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

Hi Ravi ,

you seemed to have hijacked the topic.
My question was very specific regarding the pages in discussion. You said you have feeling that there is gaps in his dating of alwars.
It would be better if you can explain it.

Murugan its always argumentative in this forum whether its myth or history.

But Alwars are for sure history and not Myth - and I would like to knowwhat gaps you have found in that.

I guess you are still in Hangover over the Murugan History debate we had year ago!

I surely do not wish to start the Murugan debate again. You are a believer and I am in search of History. No use we two arguing.
Writer of History can base his arguments and on what is found and what can be proved or at least tentatively proved/accepted.
Myth and history can never co exist. Your argument can also be held against various Indian Scholars then - Romila Thapar, Jesudasan and other major Tamil Scholars. It has no western mind applied to it. If finding evidenceto validate a claim is western mind - then I am here to welcome it. Archeology,numismatic are product of western mind.

Lets put this talk very specific to Alwars else we are entering the labyrinth again.

Regards,
Vairam

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Dear Vairam

Dr.Zvelebil was an undisputed scholar who came in from the west and studied Dravidian history more than any of us can even imagine. I have neverdisputed that, will never do that too, in that count.

However, please understand that there MUST be a base line for anything, no one can start any such colossal work without having a base line, a starting point. For many of us it was PS or SS or something similar. For Dr.Zvelebil, who or what was it?

I believe it could have been from Odysseus the Greek hero of Trojan War (he mentions about this fav char in his article Hippalos).
Dr.Zvelebil, was very much knowledgeable and interested in the Greek myth apart from various languages. He even made a comparative study of Muruga with Dionysus. Again, nothing wrong!

He was more interested in the History of Tamil Literature than theliterature itself.

For me, there in is one of the issues. I believe the literature and history of literature are very closely intertwined, my mythological foundation makes it believe so, a hard line western or dk thought may not be so.

Dr.Zvelebil wrote history, not the biography of Murugan. He is entitled to the crown on his historical findings, though a study on Muruga is never complete 'even' with a total analysis of Guru Arunagiri's works.

As said by the Guru: "Ariya ariya ariyaatha, adigal ariya, adiyeenum,arivul ariyum arivura, arulvaaye"

I have read his translation on Anubuthi, one of Guru's works. I noticed that he was emphasizing on the literal value of the poem, while Guru Arunagiri (even according to Dr.Zvelebil) who was not just a simple poet.

Ex: Verse 51, Guru Arunagiri uses the term `Guhane', which by itself makes a mile of difference ? the usage of that term, on how a person approaches a specific concept, there is the difference between literacy and historical interpretation of literacy. I think I had written about this earlier too.

I am not convinced on his theory on Cur becoming Curan etc, so the location of Mahendrapuram is dismissed as myth and obviously many such thoughts on the subject. While it is difficult to excavate a city from a spot such as where Mahendrapuram would have existed to prove it was there, it is also difficult to prove ?it was not there.
Tarakasuran is termed as a Northern demon, later linked with Suran asa brother etc. To some degree, there seems to be a named similarity, with a demon that was possessing similar qualities somewhere in the southern vindya ranges. Thiruthani is said to be a resting place for the Lord post Tarakasuran destruction, again history has no clue for it. I believe Thiruthaniexistance is way before pallava time, i had this question posed before too.

I do not see the difference between Bogar's palani and Thiru avinankudi analysis as much as I would like to see. Bogar's age ? his time line of alchemy practice vs. construction of palani idol, why there and not at Avinan kudi?

When 1800 year old pallava construction (and sangam works below it) was only found in 2008/9 even so it was near to the great pagodas, the odds of real history of Murugan not being clearly found is quite possible.

Ultimately, does he conclude the existence of Murugan after all this research?

Dr.Zvelebil does have excellent work accomplished, I am humble enoughto accept that I neither posses the qualification nor the experience to question his findings. However, just like him, I am entitled to my opinion.

Nearly 40 years of Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we are.

Tamilian, is a feeling that does not tie an age factor or research toit, Dr.Zvelebil was a tamil by heart, agreed ? purely due to his dedication on research of these ancient works, which not many dare to tread.

However, to generalize the words `than we are' may not be very relevant in all comparisons.

Today, there are many excellent tamil scholars who can read these literature ? just as literature and not as an embodied sweat of bhakti cult or belief/faith in the Ultimate. That takes the soul out of these writings,though it makes them a good read some times even with awe.

However, I would price these lower than any contemporary classic, even say they be Sanskrit adopted like tamilian kanda puranam.
These poets are tamil too, and nothing wrong with their opinions, though many do not agree.

PS: That I read thiru murugatru padai, I may possess some argumentative qualities of Nakkirar 

- R
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

Hi Ravi,
Dr.Zvelebil most of the time, acts just as accumulator of data in his book Tamil literature. He consolidates all the dating given by various scholar till his time and gives his explanation for his dating. He leaves tothe reader to accumulate the data and make up their minds.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I sure by making this comment you have read the page 152 to 161 of his great work Tamil Literature. As usual he has given dating of all Indianscholars and his dating. So it would be really helpful to all members of the group if you can let us know the important gaps he has left in these pages.

I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and cultural onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a base line that starts with a western ideology.
Unlike George L Hart or A K Ramanujan - his works have never been controversial. He was more interested in the History of Tamil Literature than the literature itself. Only other western scholar to my knowledge who hasdone research on Tamil history is JR Marr (his great work - The Eight Anthologies).
He was one of the western scholars to have put weight behind the claim for Tamil as a classical Language(argued literary in every book of his , how ancient the language was - in a time where Tamil was belived to an of0 he has done field research in Tamil. Nearly 40 years of Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we are(N.Ganesan sir pointed out he calls his daughter Kanamma). I request you to read his short biography by Dr.Elangovan inhis blog http://muelangovan.blogspot.com/2008/11/17-11-1927.html

So put such charge on him would require some valid reasons from you, which I am sure you would have it. I wouldbe interested to hear your views on Dr.Zvelebil's works.

Regards,
Vairam
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

History does not account for various stories and tales of the bard, which seems to be having many lines of history before being sung.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and cultural onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a base line that starts with a western ideology.

Nothing wrong, but then there are gaps that can derail a train.

- Alvargal Kaala Nilai (ஆழ்வார்கள் கால நிலை) (work on the historical
dating of Alwars)

Actually for this topic you can refer to Kamil Zvelebil's TamilLiterature. One good thing about this book is he compares dating of various scholars. Usually after 1975 all works quote this book for dating of various literature.

dear tms

- Alvargal Kaala Nilai (ஆழ்வார்கள் கால நிலை) (work on the historical
dating of Alwars)

his works have been recently nationalised.

good questions venkat

Karaikkal ammai and kannapar are the most early.

Below, clarifications from Sri Subramaniam ( his site
http://www.geocities.com/nayanmars/) - great teacher - mostof my posts on
periapurnam panels of darasuram are with his blessings and guidance ( must
thank Dhivakar sir once again for introducing him to me)

Kannappar is mentioned by manikkavasagar in tiruvasagam, while the
language used by ammai dates her between 2 - 5th C and not later than that
for sure.

Ammai:

http://www.thevaara m.org/thirumurai _1/nayanmar_ view.php?nayan_idField=
16

இவரது யாப்பமைதி சொற்பொருள் அமைதி முதலியவற்றைக் கொண்டு ஆராயுங்கால் இவரது
காலம் இருண்ட காலப்பகுதி எனப்படும். கி.பி. நான்கு அல்லது ஐந்தாம்
நூற்றாண்டாகக் கொள்ளலாம் என்பதும் ஆய்வாளர்களின் கருத்தாகும்.

Mention of kannappar in Tiruvasagam by manikkavasa gar
http://www.tamilnat ion.org/sathyam/ east/thiruvasaga m/tvasagam10. htm

*திருக்கோத்தும்பி - சிவனோடு ஐக்கியம்*
(தில்லையில் அருளியது- நாலடித் தரவு கொச்சகக் கலிப்பா)

பூவேறு கோனும் புரந்தரனும் பொற்பமைந்த
நாவேறு செல்வியும் நாரணணும் நான் மறையும்
மாவேறு சோதியும் வானவருந் தாமறியாச்
சேவேறு சேவடிக்கே சென்றுதாய் கோத்தும்பீ. 215

நானார் என் உள்ளமார் ஞானங்க ளார் என்னை யாரறிவார்
வானோர் பிரானென்னை ஆண்டிலனேல் மதிமயங்கி
ஊனா ருடைதலையில் உண்பலிதேர் அம்பலவன்
தேனார் கமலமே சென்றூதாய் கோத்தும்பீ. 216

தினைத்தனை உள்ளதோர் பூவினில் தேன்உண்ணாதே
நினைத்தொறும் காண்தொறும் பேசுந்தொறும் எப்போதும்
அனைத்தெலும் புள்நெக ஆனந்தத் தேன் சொரியும்
குனிப்புடையானுக்கே சென்றூதாய் கோத்தும்பீ. 217

*கண்ணப்பன்** ??'ப்பதோர் அன்பின்மை கண்டபின் *
என்னப்பன் என்னொப்பில் என்னையும் ஆட்கொண்டருளி
வண்ணப் பணித்தென்னை வாவென்ற வான் கருணைச்
கண்ணப்பென் நீற்றற்கே சென்றூதாய் கோத்தும்பீ. 218

http://www.poetryinstone.in
Here the language of stone surpasses the language of man

On Mon, Aug 31, 2009 at 2:26 AM, TM Sunder wrote:

It is difficult to determine decisively who is ancient among the
nayanmars, nor the Thiruthondar Puranam that lists hagiography of 63 saints
and 9 Thogai adiyargal is conclusively exhaustive. For example, Auvayar is
not in the list. There are countless devotees over the ages have
dedicated themselves to the pathway to realization of God through bhakti.

Maani-k-ka vasagar is perhaps oldest in the list of 63.

TMS

I fully agree with you, Ravi.

My English Professor, defined king as a small emperor and emperor as a
big king.

History, when proved, is a small or a portion myth; and, when validated
history is proved false, it again becomes a myth. Myth is also history
in a sense, because we have several versions of myths, as we have
several versions of history (jinnah, freedom movement, partition, role
of Gandhi etc.)

It is preferable not to get swayed or bulldozed by the 'scientific' tag
attached to extrapolated and biased versions of 'history'.

Sampath
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Hello Vairam

Enna sir periya varthai, hijack, ellam solaringa... :-) I have posed
the gap questions on the previous email (Refer Sooran - Mahendra puram

etc).

Alwars are real, but what they sung were a myth..(??).
If one alwar used another one's theory as a base line, it makes sense
on the base line start concept, which again comes back to me that

Dr.Zvelebil may have had a western base line.

If Murugan is a myth, then why are there so much different historical
references ? Poratha kulapathukku, pal veru Murugan vere, version

control problem irukke?

Ancient Dravidian Murugan or Ceyyon, was still a myth to start with...
according to Dr.Zvelebil and other western scholars??. In this

case,history has no standing without the strong myth background.

Myth-History may not always,coexist, especially where history has many
patches where as myth does not, it is, but natural, that history MUST be

proper in its explanations.And historians must have a convincing record
to prove when researching myth or our foundational thoughts.If our
current human mind cannot comprehend, we cannot conclude that this is a
bard's tale and cannot be real.

Without Murugan the myth, what would have been a start for this
research anyway.

Itheppadi irukkuna, there is a story about a mid sea accident with no
survivors, what an oxymoron! If there are no survivors, how does the

story come by?

I am a believer, but I do have a rational thought. I do not question
all the contemporary historical thoughts, Simply those that do not make

sense.

As much as yourself or Dr.Zvelebil(rest his soul), I am in search of
Murugan, just that I expect him in reality.If history can show me where

he is or what he is, it would make my life more easy and possibly a
short cut :-).

Heinrich Schliemann found Troy, exactly where Iliad stated Troy was,
now that is myth becoming history. Troy is not without Achilles or

Hector, but then was Achillies the son of Thetis - a sea nymph.

Troy is real - history it became one from the myth, but just because
Achilles's birth data is not documented or found, we cannot, until then

say Thetis was not a sea nymph, how ever hard it would be for our
scientific mind to accept.

-R

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99" vairam@ wrote:

Hi Ravi ,

you seemed to have hijacked the topic.
My question was very specific regarding the pages in discussion. You
said you have feeling that there is gaps in his dating of alwars.
It would be better if you can explain it.

Murugan its always argumentative in this forum whether its myth or
history.

But Alwars are for sure history and not Myth - and I would like to
know what gaps you have found in that.

I guess you are still in Hangover over the Murugan History debate we
had year ago!

I surely do not wish to start the Murugan debate again. You are a
believer and I am in search of History. No use we two arguing.
Writer of History can base his arguments and on what is found and
what can be proved or at least tentatively proved/accepted.
Myth and history can never co exist. Your argument can also be held
against various Indian Scholars then - Romila Thapar, Jesudasan and

other major Tamil Scholars. It has no western mind applied to it. If
finding evidence to validate a claim is western mind - then I am here to
welcome it. Archeology,numismatic are product of western mind.

Lets put this talk very specific to Alwars else we are entering the
labyrinth again.

Regards,
Vairam

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Dear Vairam

Dr.Zvelebil was an undisputed scholar who came in from the west
and studied Dravidian history more than any of us can even imagine. I

have never disputed that, will never do that too, in that count.

However, please understand that there MUST be a base line for
anything, no one can start any such colossal work without having a base

line, a starting point. For many of us it was PS or SS or something
similar. For Dr.Zvelebil, who or what was it?

I believe it could have been from Odysseus the Greek hero of
Trojan War (he mentions about this fav char in his article Hippalos).
Dr.Zvelebil, was very much knowledgeable and interested in the
Greek myth apart from various languages. He even made a comparative

study of Muruga with Dionysus. Again, nothing wrong!

He was more interested in the History of Tamil Literature than
the literature itself.

For me, there in is one of the issues. I believe the literature
and history of literature are very closely intertwined, my mythological

foundation makes it believe so, a hard line western or dk thought may
not be so.

Dr.Zvelebil wrote history, not the biography of Murugan. He is
entitled to the crown on his historical findings, though a study on

Muruga is never complete 'even' with a total analysis of Guru
Arunagiri's works.

As said by the Guru: "Ariya ariya ariyaatha, adigal ariya,
adiyeenum,arivul ariyum arivura, arulvaaye"

I have read his translation on Anubuthi, one of Guru's works. I
noticed that he was emphasizing on the literal value of the poem, while

Guru Arunagiri (even according to Dr.Zvelebil) who was not just a simple
poet.

Ex: Verse 51, Guru Arunagiri uses the term `Guhane', which by
itself makes a mile of difference ? the usage of that term, on how a

person approaches a specific concept, there is the difference between
literacy and historical interpretation of literacy. I think I had
written about this earlier too.

I am not convinced on his theory on Cur becoming Curan etc, so the
location of Mahendrapuram is dismissed as myth and obviously many such

thoughts on the subject. While it is difficult to excavate a city from a
spot such as where Mahendrapuram would have existed to prove it was
there, it is also difficult to prove ?it was not there.

Tarakasuran is termed as a Northern demon, later linked with Suran
as a brother etc. To some degree, there seems to be a named similarity,

with a demon that was possessing similar qualities somewhere in the
southern vindya ranges. Thiruthani is said to be a resting place for the
Lord post Tarakasuran destruction, again history has no clue for it. I
believe Thiruthani existance is way before pallava time, i had this
question posed before too.

I do not see the difference between Bogar's palani and Thiru
avinankudi analysis as much as I would like to see. Bogar's age ?

his time line of alchemy practice vs. construction of palani idol, why
there and not at Avinan kudi?

When 1800 year old pallava construction (and sangam works below
it) was only found in 2008/9 even so it was near to the great pagodas,

the odds of real history of Murugan not being clearly found is quite
possible.

Ultimately, does he conclude the existence of Murugan after all
this research?

Dr.Zvelebil does have excellent work accomplished, I am humble
enough to accept that I neither posses the qualification nor the

experience to question his findings. However, just like him, I am
entitled to my opinion.

Nearly 40 years of Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we
are.

Tamilian, is a feeling that does not tie an age factor or research
to it, Dr.Zvelebil was a tamil by heart, agreed ? purely due to his

dedication on research of these ancient works, which not many dare to
tread.

However, to generalize the words `than we are' may not be very
relevant in all comparisons.

Today, there are many excellent tamil scholars who can read these
literature ? just as literature and not as an embodied sweat of

bhakti cult or belief/faith in the Ultimate. That takes the soul out of
these writings, though it makes them a good read some times even with
awe.

However, I would price these lower than any contemporary classic,
even say they be Sanskrit adopted like tamilian kanda puranam.
These poets are tamil too, and nothing wrong with their opinions,
though many do not agree.

PS: That I read thiru murugatru padai, I may possess some
argumentative qualities of Nakkirar 
- R
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

Hi Ravi,
Dr.Zvelebil most of the time, acts just as accumulator of data
in his book Tamil literature. He consolidates all the dating given by

various scholar till his time and gives his explanation for his dating.
He leaves to the reader to accumulate the data and make up their minds.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and
research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I sure by making this comment you have read the page 152 to 161
of his great work Tamil Literature. As usual he has given dating of all

Indian scholars and his dating. So it would be really helpful to all
members of the group if you can let us know the important gaps he has
left in these pages.

I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and
cultural onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a
base line that starts with a western ideology.
Unlike George L Hart or A K Ramanujan - his works have never
been controversial. He was more interested in the History of Tamil

Literature than the literature itself. Only other western scholar to my
knowledge who has done research on Tamil history is JR Marr (his great
work - The Eight Anthologies).

He was one of the western scholars to have put weight behind the
claim for Tamil as a classical Language(argued literary in every book of

his , how ancient the language was - in a time where Tamil was belived
nearly 1990 he has done field research in Tamil. Nearly 40 years of
Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we are(N.Ganesan sir pointed
out he calls his daughter Kanamma). I request you to read his short
biography by Dr.Elangovan in his blog
http://muelangovan.blogspot.com/2008/11/17-11-1927.html

So put such charge on him would require some valid reasons from
you , which I am sure you would have it. I wouldbe interested to hear

your views on Dr.Zvelebil's works.

Regards,
Vairam
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds" wrote:

History does not account for various stories and tales of the
bard, which seems to be having many lines of history before being sung.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and
research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and
cultural onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a
base line that starts with a western ideology.

Nothing wrong, but then there are gaps that can derail a
train.

dating of Alwars)

Tamil Literature. One good thing about this book is he compares dating

of various scholars. Usually after 1975 all works quote this book for
dating of various literature.

the wisdom of the
ancients.

- Alvargal Kaala Nilai
(ஆழ்வார்கள் கால நிலை)

(work on the historical

dating of Alwars)
- Alvargal Varalaru (historical sketches on alwars).

his works have been recently nationalised.

good questions venkat

Karaikkal ammai and kannapar are the most early.

Below, clarifications from Sri Subramaniam ( his site
http://www.geocities.com/nayanmars/) - great teacher -
most of my posts on
periapurnam panels of darasuram are with his blessings
and guidance ( must
thank Dhivakar sir once again for introducing him to me)

Kannappar is mentioned by manikkavasagar in tiruvasagam,
while the
language used by ammai dates her between 2 - 5th C and
not later than that
for sure.

Ammai:

http://www.thevaara m.org/thirumurai _1/nayanmar_
view.php? nayan_idField=

16

=16

இவரது யாப்பமைதி
சொற்பொருள் அமைதி

முதலியவற்றைக்
கொண்டு ஆராயுங்கால்
இவரது

காலம் இருண்ட
காலப்பகுதி

எனப்படும். கி.பி.
நான்கு அல்லது
ஐந்தாம்

நூற்றாண்டாகக்
கொள்ளலாம் என்பதும்

ஆய்வாளர்களின்
கருத்தாகும்.

Mention of kannappar in Tiruvasagam by manikkavasa gar
http://www.tamilnat ion.org/sathyam/ east/thiruvasaga
m/tvasagam10.

htm

*திருக்கோத்தும்பி -

சிவனோடு ஐக்கியம்*

(தில்லையில்
அருளியது- நாலடித்

தரவு கொச்சகக்
கலிப்பா)

பூவேறு கோனும்
புரந்தரனும்

பொற்பமைந்த

நாவேறு
செல்வியும் நாரணணும்

நான் மறையும்

மாவேறு சோதியும்
வானவருந் தாமறியாச்
சேவேறு
சேவடிக்கே

சென்றுதாய்
கோத்தும்பீ. 215

நானார் என்
உள்ளமார் ஞானங்க

ளார் என்னை யாரறிவார்

வானோர்
பிரானென்னை

ஆண்டிலனேல் மதிமயங்கி

ஊனா ருடைதலையில்
உண்பலிதேர் அம்பலவன்
தேனார் கமலமே
சென்றூதாய்

கோத்தும்பீ. 216

தினைத்தனை
உள்ளதோர் பூவினில்

தேன்உண்ணாதே

நினைத்தொறும்
காண்தொறும்

பேசுந்தொறும்
எப்போதும்

அனைத்தெலும்
புள்நெக ஆனந்தத்

தேன் சொரியும்

குனிப்புடையானுக்கே

சென்றூதாய்
கோத்தும்பீ. 217

*கண்ணப்பன்**
??'ப்பதோர் அன்பின்மை

கண்டபின் *

என்னப்பன்
என்னொப்பில்

என்னையும்
ஆட்கொண்டருளி

வண்ணப்
பணித்தென்னை வாவென்ற

வான் கருணைச்

கண்ணப்பென்
நீற்றற்கே

சென்றூதாய்

among the
nayanmars, nor the Thiruthondar Puranam that lists
hagiography of 63 saints
and 9 Thogai adiyargal is conclusively exhaustive. For
example, Auvayar is
not in the list. There are countless devotees over the
ages have
dedicated themselves to the pathway to realization of

Kannappar

Hello Vairam

Enna sir periya varthai, hijack, ellam solaringa... :-) I have posed the gap questions on the previous email (Refer Sooran - Mahendra puram etc).

Alwars are real, but what they sung were a myth..(??).
If one alwar used another one's theory as a base line, it makes sense on the base line start concept, which again comes back to me that Dr.Zvelebil may have had a western base line.

If Murugan is a myth, then why are there so much different historical references ? Poratha kulapathukku, pal veru Murugan vere, version control problem irukke?

Ancient Dravidian Murugan or Ceyyon, was still a myth to start with... according to Dr.Zvelebil and other western scholars??. In this case,history hasno standing without the strong myth background.

Myth-History may not always,coexist, especially where history has many patches where as myth does not, it is, but natural, that history MUST be properin its explanations.And historians must have a convincing record to prove when researching myth or our foundational thoughts.If our current human mind cannot comprehend, we cannot conclude that this is a bard's tale and cannot be real.

Without Murugan the myth, what would have been a start for this research anyway.

Itheppadi irukkuna, there is a story about a mid sea accident with no survivors, what an oxymoron! If there are no survivors, how does the story come by?

I am a believer, but I do have a rational thought. I do not question all the contemporary historical thoughts, Simply those that do not make sense.

As much as yourself or Dr.Zvelebil(rest his soul), I am in search of Murugan, just that I expect him in reality.If history can show me where he is or what he is, it would make my life more easy and possibly a short cut :-).

Heinrich Schliemann found Troy, exactly where Iliad stated Troy was, now that is myth becoming history. Troy is not without Achilles or Hector, but then was Achillies the son of Thetis - a sea nymph.
Troy is real - history it became one from the myth, but just because Achilles's birth data is not documented or found, we cannot, until then say Thetis was not a sea nymph, how ever hard it would be for our scientific mind toaccept.

-R

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

Dear Vairam

Dr.Zvelebil was an undisputed scholar who came in from the west and studied Dravidian history more than any of us can even imagine. I have never disputed that, will never do that too, in that count.

However, please understand that there MUST be a base line for anything,no one can start any such colossal work without having a base line, a starting point. For many of us it was PS or SS or something similar. For Dr.Zvelebil, who or what was it?

I believe it could have been from Odysseus the Greek hero of Trojan War(he mentions about this fav char in his article Hippalos).
Dr.Zvelebil, was very much knowledgeable and interested in the Greek myth apart from various languages. He even made a comparative study of Murugawith Dionysus. Again, nothing wrong!

He was more interested in the History of Tamil Literature than the literature itself.

For me, there in is one of the issues. I believe the literature and history of literature are very closely intertwined, my mythological foundationmakes it believe so, a hard line western or dk thought may not be so.

Dr.Zvelebil wrote history, not the biography of Murugan. He is entitledto the crown on his historical findings, though a study on Muruga is nevercomplete 'even' with a total analysis of Guru Arunagiri's works.

As said by the Guru: "Ariya ariya ariyaatha, adigal ariya, adiyeenum,arivul ariyum arivura, arulvaaye"

I have read his translation on Anubuthi, one of Guru's works. I noticedthat he was emphasizing on the literal value of the poem, while Guru Arunagiri (even according to Dr.Zvelebil) who was not just a simple poet.

Ex: Verse 51, Guru Arunagiri uses the term `Guhane', which by itself makes a mile of difference ? the usage of that term, on how a person approaches a specific concept, there is the difference between literacy and historical interpretation of literacy. I think I had written about this earlier too.

I am not convinced on his theory on Cur becoming Curan etc, so the location of Mahendrapuram is dismissed as myth and obviously many such thoughtson the subject. While it is difficult to excavate a city from a spot such as where Mahendrapuram would have existed to prove it was there, it is alsodifficult to prove ?it was not there.
Tarakasuran is termed as a Northern demon, later linked with Suran as abrother etc. To some degree, there seems to be a named similarity, with a demon that was possessing similar qualities somewhere in the southern vindya ranges. Thiruthani is said to be a resting place for the Lord post Tarakasuran destruction, again history has no clue for it. I believe Thiruthani existance is way before pallava time, i had this question posed before too.

I do not see the difference between Bogar's palani and Thiru avinankudianalysis as much as I would like to see. Bogar's age ? his time line of alchemy practice vs. construction of palani idol, why there and not at Avinan kudi?

When 1800 year old pallava construction (and sangam works below it) wasonly found in 2008/9 even so it was near to the great pagodas, the odds ofreal history of Murugan not being clearly found is quite possible.

Ultimately, does he conclude the existence of Murugan after all this research?

Dr.Zvelebil does have excellent work accomplished, I am humble enough to accept that I neither posses the qualification nor the experience to question his findings. However, just like him, I am entitled to my opinion.

Nearly 40 years of Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we are.

Tamilian, is a feeling that does not tie an age factor or research to it, Dr.Zvelebil was a tamil by heart, agreed ? purely due to his dedication on research of these ancient works, which not many dare to tread.

However, to generalize the words `than we are' may not be very relevantin all comparisons.

Today, there are many excellent tamil scholars who can read these literature ? just as literature and not as an embodied sweat of bhakti cult orbelief/faith in the Ultimate. That takes the soul out of these writings, though it makes them a good read some times even with awe.

However, I would price these lower than any contemporary classic, even say they be Sanskrit adopted like tamilian kanda puranam.
These poets are tamil too, and nothing wrong with their opinions, though many do not agree.

PS: That I read thiru murugatru padai, I may possess some argumentativequalities of Nakkirar 

- R
--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

Hi Ravi,
Dr.Zvelebil most of the time, acts just as accumulator of data in hisbook Tamil literature. He consolidates all the dating given by various scholar till his time and gives his explanation for his dating. He leaves to the reader to accumulate the data and make up their minds.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I sure by making this comment you have read the page 152 to 161 of his great work Tamil Literature. As usual he has given dating of all Indian scholars and his dating. So it would be really helpful to all members of thegroup if you can let us know the important gaps he has left in these pages.

I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and cultural onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a base line that starts with a western ideology.
Unlike George L Hart or A K Ramanujan - his works have never been controversial. He was more interested in the History of Tamil Literature than the literature itself. Only other western scholar to my knowledge who has done research on Tamil history is JR Marr (his great work - The Eight Anthologies).
He was one of the western scholars to have put weight behind the claim for Tamil as a classical Language(argued literary in every book of his , how ancient the language was - in a time where Tamil was belived to an off he has done field research in Tamil. Nearly 40 years of Tamil study- makes him more Tamilian than we are(N.Ganesan sir pointed out he calls his daughter Kanamma). I request you to read his short biography by Dr.Elangovan in his blog http://muelangovan.blogspot.com/2008/11/17-11-1927.html

So put such charge on him would require some valid reasons from you ,which I am sure you would have it. I wouldbe interested to hear your viewson Dr.Zvelebil's works.

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "ravi_eds"

History does not account for various stories and tales of the bard,which seems to be having many lines of history before being sung.

Even though Zvelebil has a good account of the time line and research, his sequence has small yet important gaps.
I am not sure if that is due to his Western native and cultural onset prior to researching dravidian scripts.
It is anything but natural that these researches would have a base line that starts with a western ideology.

Nothing wrong, but then there are gaps that can derail a train.

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, "vairam99"

- Alvargal Kaala Nilai (ஆழ்வார்கள் கால நிலை) (work on the historical
dating of Alwars)

Actually for this topic you can refer to Kamil Zvelebil's Tamil Literature. One good thing about this book is he compares dating of various scholars. Usually after 1975 all works quote this book for dating of various literature.

Thanks to today internet, google and chat windows - plus the wisdom of the
ancients.
I really amazes me to know I have never met or talked to VJ. But Nearly every day in the last 1-1/2 years we have been in contact thanks to google chat!

Regards,
Vairam

--- In ponniyinselvan@yahoogroups.com, vj kumar

dear tms

Thanks to today internet, google and chat windows - plus the wisdom of the
ancients. Anyway, does anyone have this work

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raghava_Iyengar

- Alvargal Kaala Nilai (ஆழ்வார்கள் கால நிலை) (work on the historical
dating of Alwars)
- Alvargal Varalaru (historical sketches on alwars).

his works have been recently nationalised.

rgds
vj

http://www.poetryinstone.in
Here the language of stone surpasses the language of man

2009/8/31 TM Sunder

Brilliant, VJ. Thanks for providing link to Sri. Subramniams'website.
